title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) – On a night when basketball history was written, Hakeem Olajuwon was not merely a player; he was a force of nature. The Detroit Pistons arrived in Houston with a game plan, but they had no answer for "The Dream," who delivered a performance for the ages, scoring a career-high and franchise-record 51 points to power the Rockets to a commanding 115-96 victory.

From the opening tip, Olajuwon was unstoppable. He carved through the Pistons' defense with an array of his signature dream shakes, feathery jump hooks, and powerful post moves. The double-teams came, but it didn't matter. The triple-teams were considered, but to no avail. Olajuwon was in a transcendent zone, scoring from the block, the baseline, and everywhere in between, turning the Summit into his personal showcase.

While the night belonged to Olajuwon, he was not without a crucial supporting cast. Clyde Drexler orchestrated the offense with 13 assists, many of them finding the hands of the unstoppable center, while adding 11 points. The Pistons, led by Grant Hill's valiant 22-point effort, simply watched the legend unfold before them, powerless to stop the onslaught.

This was more than just a win; it was a coronation. Olajuwon’s 51 points, a staggering figure that would stand as a Rockets benchmark, cemented his legacy on a night where one man’s brilliance overshadowed everything else. In the annals of the game, when they speak of legendary individual performances, Hakeem Olajuwon’s masterpiece against the Pistons will forever echo.
